keqe_expansions: Turnips are root vegetables that belong to the Brassicaceae family, which also includes cabbage, broccoli, and radishes. These versatile vegetables have a crisp texture and a slightly peppery flavor. Turnips can be consumed raw in salads or slaws, or cooked by boiling, steaming, roasting, or sautéing. They are a good source of nutrients such as vitamin C, fiber, and potassium. Turnips are often used in a variety of dishes, including soups, stews, and casseroles, adding a unique flavor and nutrition to the meal. Additionally, turnip greens are also edible and can be cooked similarly to other leafy greens like spinach or kale. Overall, turnips are a nutritious and delicious vegetable that can be enjoyed in many different culinary applications.

Turnips are root vegetables that belong to the cabbage family. They have a round shape with a white or purple skin and a crisp white flesh. Turnips are commonly cooked by boiling, roasting, or mashing, and can be enjoyed in a variety of dishes such as soups, stews, and salads. They are a versatile vegetable with a slightly peppery flavor that can add depth and complexity to many recipes. Turnips are also a good source of vitamins, minerals, and fiber, making them a nutritious addition to a balanced diet. Overall, turnips are a delicious and healthy vegetable that can be a flavorful addition to your meals.

top_passages: Microbiological examination of vegetable seed sprouts in Korea.	Sprouted vegetable seeds used as food have been implicated as sources of outbreaks of Salmonella and Escherichia coli O157:H7 infections. We profiled the microbiological quality of sprouts and seeds sold at retail shops in Seoul, Korea. Ninety samples of radish sprouts and mixed sprouts purchased at department stores, supermarkets, and traditional markets and 96 samples of radish, alfalfa, and turnip seeds purchased from online stores were analyzed to determine the number of total aerobic bacteria (TAB) and molds or yeasts (MY) and the incidence of Salmonella, E. coli O157:H7, and Enterobacter sakazakii. Significantly higher numbers of TAB (7.52 log

Glucosinolates in Brassica vegetables: the influence of the food supply chain on intake, bioavailability and human health.	Glucosinolates (GLSs) are found in Brassica vegetables. Examples of these sources include cabbage, Brussels sprouts, broccoli, cauliflower and various root vegetables (e.g. radish and turnip). A number of epidemiological studies have identified an inverse association between consumption of these vegetables and the risk of colon and rectal cancer. Animal studies have shown changes in enzyme activities and DNA damage resulting from consumption of Brassica vegetables or isothiocyanates, the breakdown products (BDP) of GLSs in the body. Mechanistic studies have begun to identify the ways in which the compounds may exert their protective action

Diet and gallbladder cancer: a case-control study.	Cancer of the gallbladder is rare but fatal, and has an unusual geographic and demographic distribution. Gallstones and obesity have been suggested as possible risk factors. As diet is known to influence both these factors, we carried out the present study to evaluate the possible role of diet in gallbladder carcinogenesis. A case-control study involving 64 newly diagnosed cases of gallbladder cancer and 101 cases of gallstones was carried out. The dietary evaluation was carried out by the dietary recall method based on a preset questionnaire developed specifically for the present study, keeping in mind the common dietary habits prevailing in this part of the world.
